Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Operational parameters in H<sub>2</sub>S biofiltration under extreme acid conditions: performance, biomass control, and CO<sub>2</sub> consumption.

AbstractText: This paper reports the treatment of gaseous hydrogen sulfide, H<sub>2</sub>S, in a biotrickling filter (BTF) under extreme acidic pH conditions (≈ 1.2). The effect of adding thiosulfate (Na<sub>2</sub>S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>.5H<sub>2</sub>O) to promote biomass growth, feeding low concentrations of ozone to control excess biomass, and the carbon dioxide, CO<sub>2</sub>, consumption by the chemolithoautotrophic consortium were evaluated. The results showed a global removal efficiency over 98.0% with loads of H<sub>2</sub>S > 50 g m<sup>-3</sup> h<sup>-1</sup> (at 639 ppmv) and a linear relation between H<sub>2</sub>S elimination capacity with the CO<sub>2</sub> consumption rate of around 0.1 gCO<sub>2</sub>/gH<sub>2</sub>S. Supplementing sulfur in the medium with 2 g L<sup>-1</sup> thiosulfate resulted in negative effect performance. Respirometry tests proved that the consortium could not utilize this sulfur form at this pH. Additionally, continuous and intermittent O<sub>3</sub> feeding to the BTF in gaseous concentrations of 98 ± 5.4 mg m<sup>-3</sup> caused a slight decreased in the performance but the biomass activity in the BTF was only slightly affected allowing a quick performance recovery once O<sub>3</sub> addition was suspended.
